column1: Azaghâl was the Lord of the Dwarves of Belegost during the First Age.
While traveling on the Dwarf-road of Beleriand in East Beleriand
column2: Azaghâl was waylaid by Orcs; Maedhros came to his rescue saving his life and treasure
column3: and as a token of gratitude
column4: the Dwarf king gave him his Dragon-helm of Dor-lómin made by Telchar.

column1: Azaghâl and his Dwarves joined the Union of Maedhros and during the Nirnaeth Arnoediad the Dwarves of Belegost covered the retreat of the Sons of Fëanor by surrounding the Dragon Glaurung.  They hewed at him with their axes
column2: for his scales were not strong enough to shield him from the blows of Dwarven axes. In his rage Glaurung struck down Azaghâl
column3: and crawled over him.  With his last breath Azaghâl drove a knife into Glaurungs belly
column4: so wounded him that he fled the field with many of the dismayed beasts of Angband following.

column1: File:Joona Kujanen - The Fall of Azaghal.jpg
The Dwarves raised up the body of their lord and bore him away; and with slow steps they walked behind singing a dirge in deep voices
column2: as it were a funeral pomp in their country
column3: and gave no heed to their foes; and none dared attack them.

column1: Azaghâl is one of the few Khuzdul names known. It is not determined whether this was his birthname or an epithet. Its meaning is not known
column2: but it has been argued that it is of the same Sundocarmë as the Adûnaic verb azgara
column3: "to wage war" and even perhaps Azog. Azaghâl would then mean "warrior".http://lalaith.vpsurf.de/Tolkien/Fr_Atani.html
